All of these animals can be spotted directly from your next lodge, an opulent base immersed in the sounds and sights of the shoreline. With its panoramic lake views, this contemporary lodge is all about the luxury extras that make safari so special. Enjoy massage treatments while watching the hippos, uncork premium wines while watching male buffalo rampage about, and admire the procession of antelopes that come for an evening drink. These two days are also privately guided, with game drives complemented by boat cruises. While Hwange is a park for adventure and exploring, Mutusadona and Lake Kariba are focused on sitting back and allowing the wildlife to come to you. Your stay includes up to three activities a day, each handcrafted to provide a new angle. Seek out leopards on mountain slopes, the spotted hunter hiding beneath a canopy of acacia trees. Walk to a herd of female buffalo, getting close to their vigorous huffing and curled horns. Cruise past herons and storks and then watch the fish eagles descend on the lake. And most of all, lie back and savor the tranquility of the African wilderness. Nothing artificial breaks the repose as you can glance up from a book to see animals wandering past, or take a nap by the pool and have a baby elephant come by to say hello. For escapism, there's little that can rival Lake Kariba and the charms of Mutusadona.

dayInfo.title: Matobo Hills – Black and White Rhinos
dayInfo.description: It will be a short flight across the central Zimbabwean plains to Bulawayo Airport, and then a quick 45-minute road transfer to Matobo Hills, a UNESCO World Heritage site of granite domes and ancient rock art. Baboons and zebra guard the entrance to the highest boulders with their black and white contrasting with the sharp red of the stone. A local guide will lead you on a journey by foot, so you will clamber high onto the boulders to explore an enchanting collection of ancient rock art. Stories are told with every painting and narrate messages that were left behind thousands of years before. Spirituality defines the atmosphere, and it will feel as though you are following in the footsteps of Zimbabwe's ancestors as every cave or rock reveals another piece of a mystical history. Tucked into an ancient San bushman shelter is your next camp, a delightful accommodation that will help you to savor the stories of the past. Panoramic views stretch out from your thatched suite as a bar and swimming pool overlook the local waterhole. This is not just a place of cultural heritage as it remains a home for many of Africa's most famous mammals. You will discover a new collection of antelopes and birds, along with the odd elephant and buffalo, and you will also enjoy exclusive experiences with both black and white rhinos. Matobo Hills has one of the finest populations of rhino anywhere in Africa, and you will see the two species side by side. As in the time of the bushmen, you can explore on foot as you enter a protected reserve that is home to over 60 rhinos. Black rhinos are bashful and hide among the bushes with their majestic horns and sturdy frames. White rhinos have a confident air and are almost double the size of their cousins. Despite the names, both are gray in color. Throughout the day, you will quickly learn to distinguish the two as you admire their contrasting lips and behavior. There are very few places in the world where it is possible to get so close to rhinos, especially black and white rhinos together and their abundance on these ancient plains will astound you.

dayInfo.title: Malilangwe Wildlife Reserve – Zimbabwe's Finest Private Reserve
dayInfo.description: Zimbabwe will impress you deeply when viewed from the air. The roads are colored a deep red as swathes of forest and grassland are interspersed by villages of thatched huts. Hills roll towards Mozambique while desert stretches out towards Botswana. Flying between safari destinations saves a huge amount of travel time and ensures you transfer directly from wilderness to wilderness, yet every journey is also a scenic flight and a chance to savor Zimbabwe from the air. You will always have a window seat in the small planes and on some flights, like the one to Malilangwe Wildlife Reserve, are private charters. Touch down in the southeastern corner of Zimbabwe and you will be surrounded by the enchantment of the Greater Kruger ecosystem. Mountain acacia woodlands and ironwood thickets are home to rhino and elephant, while huge baobab trees are as constant as the giraffe. Life revolves around a central lake, the permanent water source for thousands of migratory animals. This is a private game reserve, and access is restricted to a handful of visitors. It is also a very compact wilderness and covers a mere 150,000 acres. In comparison, Hwange National Park is bigger than some US states allowing for a greater sense of intimacy with the landscape. In essence, Malilangwe is like the Greater Kruger in miniature as it pieces together diverse wildlife and habitats. This region is also home to Zimbabwe's most opulent accommodation. A wood-burning fireplace will dominate your huge sitting room as a viewing deck provides 270-degree views over the savanna. Your personal bar will be stocked with premium wines and spirits while a personal butler will attend to anything you need. Step out of your gorgeous suite and into your bubbling private hot tub that has an endless view. There is also a spa, an old-world library, and various places to enjoy fine dining in the bush. After your adventure around Zimbabwe, this beautiful property is where you will come to reenergize and savor the incredible comforts. Of course, you must also prepare for a thrilling safari experience as you watch lions pride follow zebra while the lionesses hide in the grass before setting an ambush. Follow the hyenas that scurry across the savanna, their strange faces accompanied by their menacing snarls. Watch an elephant tower over your vehicle and then spot a small herd using their trunks as snorkels. There is a lot to see in a short time, with morning and afternoon game drives celebrating the best of an African safari. You can also head out on bush walks ranging from 30-minute journeys to entire mornings spent on the savanna. When each activity ends, the luxury of your lodge is ideal for watching the rest of the wildlife wander by.

dayInfo.title: Harare – Departure
dayInfo.description: After a relaxed morning, you will fly from Malilangwe Wildlife Reserve to Harare to connect with your international departure. Your game drive to the airstrip is a chance to savor the African savanna and you journey past the famous mammals that have been a constant on this 13-day journey.

tourName: Into the Wild: Zimbabwe Walking & Canoeing Safari
placesVisited: Victoria Falls, Matusadona National Park, Mana Pools National Park, Chirundu, Hwange National Park
generalInfo: Safari is different in Zimbabwe. Walk across landscapes of rhinos and elephants, canoe through rivers of big game, and feel a deep connection with the wild. Combine a 4-day canoe expedition with days spent walking in the bush, and this exclusive adventure provides a new perspective on African safari. You will find yourself listening, smelling, looking and feeling as all of your senses will be inspired on this intrepid journey into areas that very rarely see people. Celebrate the authenticity and wonder of a big-game world.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – Arrival on the Zambezi
dayInfo.description: Touch down in Victoria Falls and transfer to your lodge by boat, a journey along the Zambezi and a quick insight into what’s to come in Mana Pools. In the coming days, you will start paddling along the Zambezi, some 600 kilometers downriver from here, where it is narrower and less daunting. From the boat, you might see hippos and elephants, legendary figures who dot the length of the Zambezi. Chacma baboons and vervet monkeys cluster in the trees overlooking the river, while prints along the riverbank suggest that antelopes are not far away. Spend the afternoon relaxing at the lodge before a sunset dinner cruise, which is gourmet and wild in equal measures.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – Majestic Viewpoints and the World’s Most Powerful Waterfall
dayInfo.description: Wake up to wild animals in the river. Then remember that this is just an introduction to Zimbabwe’s wildlife. There is much more to discover in the days to come. Victoria Falls is just two miles downriver from the lodge, and you are staying close to the country’s busiest tourist town – yet the landscape is dominated by animals. After a relaxed morning, you are transferred to the falls where a thrilling self-guided walking trail runs parallel to the thundering whitewater. At some places, the views are magnificent, with 360-degree rainbows swirling in the mist, or millions of gallons of gushing water stretching onwards for a mile. At other times you get soaked, the mist raining down, exemplifying the power of this waterfall. Explore at your own pace then head back to the lodge, where a second sunset dinner cruise continues the encounters with hippos and baboons.

dayInfo.title: Kariba �– Getting Ready for the Canoeing Adventure
dayInfo.description: The 4-day canoeing adventure starts from Lake Kariba, where the water of Africa’s Riviera diverts into the lower section of the Zambezi River. Fly to Lake Kariba by light aircraft and spend the morning on a game drive in Matusadona National Park, getting first glimpses of lions and rhinos. Enjoy a picnic lunch on the savannah, then keep exploring into the afternoon, preparing for the canoeing adventure by discovering a huge variety of different mammals. Later in the afternoon, you are transferred to the north of the lake and a luxury waterfront lodge in Kariba. It feels like the edge of the world here. Tomorrow you will be paddling off the edge, into a canyon and a long stretch of river that is completely inaccessible by vehicle.

dayInfo.title: Chirundu – Paddling Through Epic Landscapes
dayInfo.description: Load up the canoe and start paddling. Your vessel is a stable 19-foot Canadian canoe, perfect for relaxed paddling and carrying your stuff through Mana Pools. There won’t be any rapids, so you are not going to tip, although you’re sometimes required to paddle away from hippo pods or elephant herds acting aggressively. The next few days follow a similar rhythm, waking early for a light breakfast in the bush then paddling for a couple of hours. Stop for a more substantial breakfast on the banks, then keep canoeing until midday, where you reach a remote Zambezi island in Mana Pools National Park. It’s hot now, so take a siesta after your lunch. Afternoons are leisurely, relaxing at the camp and enjoying a walking safari in the surrounding riverine woodland area. On this safari, you will paddle the full length of Mana Pools National Park. It is a leisurely journey, following the river downstream. Today’s first stretch is light on wildlife but big on epic landscapes. Deep, silent gorges rise above you, glowing through red and orange tones as the morning sun rises. The seclusion is absolute, just a couple of canoes and the enormity of the Zambezi canyons. You will have seen a similar canyon at Victoria Falls; this section close to Chirundu is higher, narrower, and only sees a few people a year. There is no access without being on the water, and you will delight in the remote atmosphere. You are sure to spot a few animals, grazers and giants who occupy the park’s remote corners, often large males cast out from their herd. Over the day, you will settle into the style of safari, feel the grandeur of nature, and spend the night on a remote uninhabited island.

dayInfo.title: Mana Pools National Park – Unique Canoe Expedition
dayInfo.description: Traveling like this almost makes you feel like a nomad. Everything feels so wild. It is like you can better appreciate the life of elephants who roam the banks, sensing that they are also on a long, intrepid journey. Perhaps most poignantly, it feels like you’re on your own journey, not simply heading out to find wildlife. Such a mindset seems to make each encounter more special. Following the Zambezi, you paddle into the game-rich central areas of the park. It is worth noting that these areas remain mostly void of other people, as most Mana Pools boat safaris concentrate on the park’s lakes. Hippos are a constant now. Large pods cluster in calm waters, with individuals casually yawning to reveal trademark jaws. Younger hippos are regularly spotted on the banks, sometimes less than 15 meters away from the canoe. Elephants make for regular encounters. There are youngsters practicing their swimming, large adults walking on the riverbed and using trunks as snorkels, plus gracious matriarchs showcasing enviable equanimity. Buffalo are also common close to the Zambezi banks, and sometimes you see a huge herd descending into the water, swimming across to Zambia. Baboons seem to be ever-present around your camp while zebras emerge with almost metronomic consistency. The camps are basic but comfortable. The encounters are legendary. From the water you see everything coming from a distance. You see the herds of waterbuck and wildebeest from afar, hear the grunting giants, watch giraffe go from distant silhouette to high-definition close-up. At water level, you have a complete perspective on the landscape, what animals are where, and which sounds are echoing endlessly. Canoeing is almost silent, so when you approach wildlife, it doesn’t run away frightened. Even lions may be spotted, a pride of predators drinking from the banks. Perhaps you see a cheetah, maybe even a leopard, lurking in the reeds. Canoeing is not just silent safari. It is also slow safari, helping you discover all the little clues and all the predatory eyes hiding along the banks.

dayInfo.title: Mana Pools National Park – Final Day Canoeing with Africa’s Giants
dayInfo.description: Stop paddling, allowing the Zambezi current to push you slowly downriver. An open floodplain is packed with animals, mostly wildebeest and zebra on their morning journey to the water. Stop the canoe by the banks and watch everything unfold, the herds marauding forward and the pride of lions lying in wait. Raucous baboons spoil the hunt, hooting fanatically to warn everyone of the camouflaged predators. The zebra and wildebeest walk downriver, looking for a more open place to drink. You watch the lions thinking, and admire the telepathic communication between females, then you see them sulk off in the opposite direction. Today you complete the canoeing, reaching the eastern edge of Mana Pools National Park by lunchtime. Spend the afternoon game driving back through the park, exploring the lakes and floodplains that were out of sight from the river. In particular, the guides are searching for the predators you haven’t seen yet. Wind into riverine woodland, scanning the branches for leopard spots. Then cross the plains, deciphering the camouflage of cheetahs in the grass. After three nights of relatively simple camping, you spend this night in a new luxury camp, enjoying a huge suite with floor-to-ceiling glass windows and a private shower beneath the night’s stars.

dayInfo.title: Hwange National Park – Relaxed Walks and Drives
dayInfo.description: A flight from Mana Pools to Hwange keeps you firmly within the wilderness, hopping from one big-game landscape to another. In the wetlands, you’ve grown accustomed to lush, vibrant colors. The Hwange savannah is a different tone completely, parched red dirt blanketed by soft orange dust. It’s harder for the cats to blend in here, and you have no trouble spotting lions and cheetahs on your introductory game drive. One pride seems to pose for the camera, sitting proudly on a rock that juts above the savannah. They approach you, slowly circling the safari vehicle before returning to their beautiful state of repose. Arrive at one of Hwange’s best camps around midday, where lunch is served and a guide introduces the style of safari. Set in its own private concession, in the east of the park, this camp is widely celebrated for having Zimbabwe’s best walking safari guides. Over these next three days, you have an open canvas to explore, with a variety of routes, all of which are highly unlikely to see other people or vehicles. You have complete flexibility. You will be driven to trailheads, then walk back to camp on foot, for two hours or the full day. Loop around waterholes close to the camp, or take a walk in remote mopane woodland, far from the camp. Mix walks and drives through the day or stick to two feet. These three days can respond to your mood, as well as the natural environment. And just like in Mana Pools, these journeys create a dramatic intimacy with the wild.

dayInfo.title: Hwange National Park – Exclusive Walking Safari
dayInfo.description: Walk slowly towards the zebra, stopping every few meters to gauge their reaction. Admire their powerful shoulder muscles and unique stripes. Then look beyond them to a herd of hartebeest, who are surrounded by a scattered herd of impala. Continue the walk and you find many more antelopes: eland and kudu close to the trees, both roan and sable antelope in the same panorama, steenbok elegantly bounding past. Many of these animals would quickly skip or canter away from a vehicle. But you are just another mammal, and the wildlife isn’t afraid. They return your gaze and inspect their visitor. You watch emotion change in a zebra’s eyes, admire the proud pouting of horned males, feel the connection with these rare and remarkable animals. Keep walking. Buffalo are up ahead but they don’t bother you, the large harem behaving very peacefully. Elephants are also up ahead, constants on the horizon. Expert guides know exactly how to respect the elephants’ space while getting you within heart-pumping proximity. A southern giraffe wanders past, then the rest of its family, including a new baby that towers above you. All the while you have not seen another person. You are fully engrossed in dozens of different species, perhaps seeing upwards of 50 unique mammals on this 3-day walking safari. Sometimes you cross plains that are inaccessible to vehicles and the atmosphere intensifies; this wonderful sense of being alone with nature is what makes a walking safari so special.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – Departure
dayInfo.description: The flight to Victoria Falls provides another insight into Zimbabwe’s landscape. It seems you see nothing artificial from the window, the west of Zimbabwe one unbroken stretch of wilderness. Touch down at the small airport in Victoria Falls and transfer on to your international departure, taking the feeling of Africa with you.

tourName: Luxury Highlights of Zimbabwe Safari in 10 Days
placesVisited: Malilangwe Wildlife Reserve, The Great Limpopo Transfrontier Park, Gonarezhou National Park, Mana Pools National Park, Zambezi River, Hwange National Park, Makalolo Concession, Victoria Falls
generalInfo: This 10-day Zimbabwe safari is a celebration of everything that Africa offers to its travelers. Enjoy a private luxury reserve with easy Big Five sightings in Malilangwe, take in a world wonder at Victoria Falls, explore a vast unchartered national park with Gonarezhou, be mesmerized by the charms of the wetlands in Mana Pools and then conclude with the drama of the savannah in Hwange. The beauty of mixing game drives with walks and boat safari will bring you an encompassing and expressive 10-days of safari experiences and cast Zimbabwe as Africa’s seductress.

dayInfo.title: Malilangwe Wildlife Reserve – An Opulent Welcome to Zimbabwe
dayInfo.description: Malilangwe is one of Southern Africa’s spheres of luxury, where you watch elephants from a private plunge pool and fine dine as lions roar in the distance. Safari is easy here with an exotic cast of animals attracted by the reserve’s permanent water that migrates into the reserve from the corners of The Great Limpopo Transfrontier Park. Operated by one of Africa’s legendary luxury names, this reserve will ease you into the safari experience, without forgoing any Western comforts. You will change planes at O. R. Tambo International in Johannesburg, flying north to this savanna in the southeast of Zimbabwe. Cocktails and champagne are served on your first afternoon game drive as silhouetted animals grace the panorama as you dine, and you only need to sit back on the balcony to enjoy many of the continent’s animals as the lodge looks over a floodlit waterhole that is populated throughout day and night.

dayInfo.title: Malilangwe Wildlife Reserve – The Charm of the Big Five in a Private Reserve
dayInfo.description: Lions are seen in the distance, basking in the morning sun with their golden manes rippling in the breeze. Elephants move gracefully past your vehicle and hidden amongst the bushes, you can spot rhinos, a mother and calf returning your gaze. Buffalo are commonplace here, and sometimes the guide must stop and wait for them to clear the rutted four-wheel drive trail. In Malilangwe, you will have an excellent chance of spotting a leopard, your guides’ intimate knowledge helping to uncover their hiding places. These are the Big Five and deserve their place as Africa’s biggest icons, and while this private reserve does not support a remarkable profusion of life, its mixed habitat provides residence for an array of life, including the famous five. The schedule will be flexible as you may wish to lie in after your journey to Africa. Activities can be tailored to your energy levels, but it is worth going on at least one game drive in search of these revered mammals. Short bush walks are a possibility, and it is possible to keep exploring in the dark with a nighttime safari about the weird and wonderful of the savanna. Malilangwe’s ease comes from its compact size as you will not need long or adventurous activities to start spotting the icons. Rather, you often just need to sit back and watch the show from your private lodge verandah or plunge pool. So soak up the luxury, tick off the famous sights, and gradually tune your senses to the wilderness.

dayInfo.title: Malilangwe Wildlife Reserve – Day Trip Safari Into the Unexplored Wilderness
dayInfo.description: On the first couple of days, you will find yourself photographing every elephant, stopping at each zebra, and delighting in every new species uncovered. But your safari is about atmosphere and immersion, about surrounding yourself with nature’s theater, not knowing what is going to happen next. Gonarezhou shares an unfenced border with Malilangwe and stretches over a vast area, butting up against South Africa and Mozambique. The region is wild and untamed, and the animals’ behavior is tinged with aggression and belligerence. Without any permanent lodges, this is one of Africa’s last big-game frontiers, mostly unexplored and certainly not understood by the human world. The animals are very similar to Malilangwe and neighboring Kruger National Park, yet they are scattered and spread, harder to find, and more likely to surprise. On a day trip, you can take a picnic and feel the thrill of an expedition as you bump through a canyon of red granite boulders, following prints in the dust. There will be a profound sense of freedom as no other people or vehicles are in sight, nor much evidence of their presence. So you can keep exploring, getting stared at by an elephant and listening to the rolling beat of hooves across the plains. When you return to Malilangwe, you will be tired and dusty, but your luxurious bathtub will be just one way to cool off and re-energize.

dayInfo.title: Mana Pools National Park – Beauty of the African Wetlands
dayInfo.description: Light aircraft connections bring both convenience and speed as they link the parks found in the different corners of Zimbabwe. While practical, your flights are also mesmerizing as the colors of the wild flow beneath your wingtips, especially on today’s flight across the Chimanimani Mountains. Coming in for a landing, you can see the park’s four permanent pools that were created by river channels that stopped flowing many centuries ago. Mana translates as “four” in the local Shona language, and these expanses of water attract all manner of wildlife throughout the dry season from April to November. You will have landed in a place of abundance with food and water to support high numbers of animals. And like revered real estate in the city, predators, and giants voraciously protect their territories. These two days are fully flexible, and after an introductory game drive, the guides will outline the different activities. In almost all parks, you must be in a vehicle for encountering the predatory cats as walking simply is not safe. But boat and canoe safaris provide a unique perspective of the carnivores not seen from above but from eye level. A lion pride stares straight back at you, perhaps a cheetah or hyena may slip silently just ten meters away, or an elephant squirts water, and you are just out of range. In Mana Pools, motorboat safaris can get you close to a larger number of animals, but a canoe safari approaches silently to bring an even greater level of intimacy. Swap wheels for walking and the animal focus is different. Avoiding the cats, guides lead you onto open floodplains, which stretch out from the four main pools – named Main, Chine, Long, and Chisambuk. Eland and kudu wander nearby, herds of impala skip past on two sides, distinguishable from the equally large herds of duiker. Sable antelope point their spiraled horns in your direction while zebra waits inquisitively as you approach. Then there are baboons and vervet monkeys, the odd mongoose poking its head out, even a harem of buffalo grunting close by. With a walking safari, there are no fences or barriers, so you move silently, and you are not seen as a threat, meaning most animals will not run away. From this inspiring perspective, you can drink in the subtleties of behavior and style, the safari experience going far beyond the obvious. Over these two days, game drives can be complemented by these unique activities, the safari always feeling new and nuanced.

dayInfo.title: Makalolo Concession – Following the Elephants Through Acacia Woodlands and Teak Forests
dayInfo.description: You will move from a landscape of abundance to one of scarcity, where the battle for survival roars in your face. Grasslands turn brown, the acacia scrub is bulldozed down by elephants, and shallow pans shrivel in the dry season sun. Somehow, Hwange is home to one of Africa’s biggest concentrations of wildlife. Hwange symbolizes the precarious balance of nature as so much is able to survive, but only the elephants and buffalo truly seem to thrive. As Zimbabwe’s largest and most famous park, some 3.4 million acres of wilderness are yours to explore. Keeping the experience exclusive, you will be staying in the private Makalolo Concession with your luxury tented camp open to nature’s sounds and the savanna as your personal playground. In this landscape, you can game drive and walk at the guides’ discretion, and diversifying the experience are the convergent habitats, such as the acacia woodlands and teak forests that are occupied by thousands upon thousands of elephants. Follow the trunks through the trees with a brass band of hoots guiding you to flapping ears and twirling trunks. The elephants will surround you, each scene imbued with intimacy as babies chase away warthogs, infants playfully bash their heads, and colossal tusks crash into tree branches with silent standoffs between herds at the waterhole. In this kind of landscape, you will not count or tick off what you see so much as you will immerse yourself in the behavior of the herds, never sure what they will do next.

dayInfo.title: Makalolo Concession – Predators Hunting Prey on the Grasslands
dayInfo.description: Out on the plains, you can see hundreds of animals in a single view. The antelope and zebra graze in the open, their sentinels pricking their ears to detect a predatory threat. Across these arid lands, there is a profusion of cats, and a few days in Hwange is a prime chance to see them prowling. They hunt in the early morning and late afternoon, as well as during the night. Sometimes you will spot lionesses inspecting their menu, looking around for a target to attack after dusk. On other drives, you will find a leopard bounding down from a tree, keeping to the high grass as a wildebeest herd plays unwittingly close. Cheetahs and wild dogs also provide mesmerizing scenes. Though usually hard to spot, these predators are relatively easy to find in Hwange. Spotted hyena charge past you at regular intervals, their snarl such a contrast to the delectable grin of the smaller brown hyena. Sometimes, you will only see the predator, but wait around, and the scene will slowly play out as the hunter biding its time in creeping ever closer to the herd. When vultures swirl, the guide will take you closer to a ragged carcass fought over by birds and jackals. On another point in the safari, you may see the actual kill or the immediate aftermath, perhaps a lion roaring with authority, mane splattered with the blood of a young zebra. All of these scenes are possible in Hwange, as well as the other parks you visit on this 10-day Zimbabwe safari, but they will never grow old.

dayInfo.title: Makalolo Concession – Continuing the Private Safari in the Heart of Hwange
dayInfo.description: Three days is the recommended minimum for Hwange, given its size and beauty. You can track scenes over multiple days, such as a hyena that is harassing a wildebeest herd one evening, and then found finishing off the carcass the next morning. Your camp is located in a private concession, so it is possible to stay close and develop a detailed understanding of the residents. Game drives can take you further afield and into the land of the elephants or that of the lions. After eight days on safari, there may be some animals you will have yet to see, so the guides can specifically tailor the game drive towards finding them. Or you might have a favorite, an animal you want to understand in more detail. Whatever the program you create with your guide, the safari will continue your rich engagement with ancient animals on lands that few people have had the fortune to explore.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – Serene Cruising on the Zambezi and Victoria Falls
dayInfo.description: Move next to the natural wonder of a spectacle of incredible power to complete your time in Zimbabwe. Fly north to spend the day at Victoria Falls and be deafened by its growling roar and enthralled by the spiraling spray. Photos do not do justice to the falls, as they are unable to represent the sheer volume and power of the water. A guide will lead you on a walking trail that runs most of the length of the falls, where there are many points for treating your senses to the enormity of it all. Then for a final evening in Zimbabwe, you will take a boat cruise down the Zambezi River as sunset colors flicker on and off the water’s surface. Tonight’s accommodation is a legendary five-star hotel that is close enough to see the clouds of spray emitted from the falls.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – Relaxed Day on the River Before Departure
dayInfo.description: Before your afternoon flight, there will be plenty of time to relax on the banks of the river and enjoy the odd troop of vervet monkeys that jump past. Take breakfast and lunch at the hotel, and then transfer to the airport for your international departure.

tourName: Multi-Country Zimbabwe and Zambia Safari
placesVisited: Harare, Matusadona National Park, Lake Kariba, Hwange National Park, Victoria Falls, Livingstone, Zambezi River, Lower Zambezi National Park, Lusaka
generalInfo: Both bafflingly beautiful and incredibly remote, there is something ineffable about the Zambezi River and its surroundings. Wilderness and wildlife thrive here as elephants and buffalo are among those that swim between countries. With eight full days of immersion in the world of big-game, this diverse safari explores the Zimbabwean and Zambian sides, from Victoria Falls to lakes of hippos, walks with rhinos to a profusion of big cats. Welcome to untouched Southern Africa, inexpressible until you experience it for yourself.

dayInfo.title: Harare – Colorful Introduction to Zimbabwe’s Capital
dayInfo.description: Harare surprises with its city center built in the 1960s and 1970s that have been mostly unchanged since, save for the coating of dust and elaborate shocks of color. Not everyone would call it attractive, but you will have a real sense of landing in Africa and being somewhere entirely unique. And while the museums are not modern, but they tell the poignant tale of the country and its past. Spending the day can be unavoidable given flight schedules, but will certainly not be a day wasted as you will be accompanied by a local guide and driver the whole time you are in Harare, picked up from the airport and given a tour of a city that hides a certain grace. The evening will be quiet, allow you to relax in the city’s best hotel as you await the safari to begin.

dayInfo.title: Matusadona National Park – Escaping Into a World of Rhinos and Hippos
dayInfo.description: Wake and your safari will begin with a purposeful white rhino barreling down the lakeshore for a long drink. Elephants grace the far banks, unmissable from afar. A roan antelope walks past, elongated horns like something from a work of fiction. Hippos open their jaws, and you will witness this scene continuously over the next two days. Gaze out over Lake Kariba, and the wide open panorama provides a baffling quantity of life, particularly the herds that graze on the open floodplains. Yet at the same time, there is an escapist quality to standing on the beach and watching the water ripple. Take the animals away, and Lake Kariba could be a vacation centered upon lounging on the beach and forgetting notions of time. You will fly to Matusadona this morning, the light aircraft touching down amongst a dusty savannah of elephant footprints. Safari is relaxed here, and Lake Kariba provides the permanent feeling of repose. Game drives move slowly through the park, wildlife easy to find as most species stay within a two-hour walk of the lake. Walks are more adventurous, especially when both rhino sub species coexist in the park. Following expert trackers and accompanied by an armed ranger, you can creep closer to the giants, admiring the boisterous bulk of the white rhinos and how they wander with an air of defiance. Smaller and much more shy, the black rhinos are one of the safari’s great indulgences with barely a thousand left in the wild. If you are on foot, you can find yourself within 50 meters of them.

dayInfo.title: Matusadona National Park – The Relaxed Start
dayInfo.description: Wake early and watch the hippos returning to their daily bathing spots, or wake late to find a scattering of antelope grazing close to the lodge. Spend the morning cruising along the lake and encounter a rich assortment of birds, many of them endemic to the waters around the Zambezi. Or spend the morning driving deeper into the bush, searching for leopards hiding in the trees, conspicuous eyes betraying their camouflage. You could spend an afternoon relaxing on the beach, or walk into buffalo country, exhilarated as a herd fiercely returns your gaze. Matusadona National Park provides one of Southern Africa’s most relaxed big-game safari experiences as it is both quiet and remote, with very few other people around. Wildlife is varied and easily spotted, and the focus is always about being able to create your own safari program.

dayInfo.title: Hwange National Park – Following the Big Cats in an Exclusive Concession
dayInfo.description: The atmosphere is completely different on the Hwange savannah. You can smell the tension as it floats through the trees and consumes every moment from mid-afternoon until late-morning. Only in the height of the heat of the day does the apprehension of the antelope cease as the lions are spotted snoozing beneath flowing acacia branches. Zimbabwe’s flagship park is connected to the Zambezi through a large protected wilderness, which merges elephant-filled woodland into the cat-dominated plains of the Kalahari. You will be staying in a private concession, where a large water-filled pan attracts four-legged mammals from the opposing habitats. Fly here from Matusadona, and it will not be long before the big cats take center stage. Lions move lazily with their paw prints close together as their golden coats shimmer in the sun. But spot them later in the day, and there is a genuine menace to this slowness as lionesses crouch as they approach the waterhole. Baboons start shouting to send a vociferous warning to everyone having a drink. Impala pin their ears and then run, leaping clear of the high grass as they disappear into the distance. An echo of hooves alerts you to a zebra herd charging away, and it will seem that the lions will not be hunting successfully now. But the tables are turned after dark, and tomorrow morning, you may spot limbs being torn from a carcass. By spending three days in Hwange, you might also see the hunt move beyond stalking to attacking.

dayInfo.title: Hwange National Park – Zimbabwe’s Flagship Safari Experience
dayInfo.description: In this private concession, with hardly any other people around, you will start to build a bigger picture of Africa’s big-game wilderness. From the verandah, you will discover what animal likes to drink and when. The procession of wildlife changes dependent on the time of day, with large elephant herds dominating the scene after dark. On game drives, you will come to understand what animals occupy where, from the herds of wildebeest and zebra on open plains to the strange antelope who hide in the trees. With walking safaris, you hone in on the individual interactions, watching how some take their turn on sentinel duty as the others graze. Hwange proudly supports more than 100 mammal species, but the safari experience centers not on the quantity, but the clarity and quality of the individual moments: a cheetah nursing her cub in the high grass, large southern giraffe arguing with their eyes, a breeding herd of elephant so proud on the savannah. While you can never tire of the famous animals, a multi-day safari allows you to look beyond the obvious and into an ancient world that brings new impressions every moment of the day. Your safari here is flexible. By combining walks and drives, you can come to appreciate the delicacies of an environment that holds many secrets. And when the activities are over, sit back on your verandah and watch the evening’s show unfold.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – The Beauty of the Falls From the Zimbabwean Side
dayInfo.description: Just a short flight north and a different phenomenon will consume your day. Victoria Falls, or as the locals know it, the Smoke that Thunders , Mosi-oa-Tunya, will take over your senses as plumes of spray rise from the chasm with rainbows swirling in the floating smoke. The water growls and groans, its baritone voice heard for miles around. From the Zimbabwean side, you can walk alongside two-thirds of the falls, much of the self-guided walking trail giving uninterrupted views across the length of the spectacle. It is on this side where you can take the best photos as various viewpoints showcase the deep, but slender, canyon and the thickness of the falling water. You will spend the night at a lodge just upriver, where a sunset cruise will continue your journey with nature.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls to Livingstone – Crossing the Famous Bridge to Zambia and Exploring David Livingstone’s Legacy
dayInfo.description: On the bridge to Zambia, you will gaze down at the Zambezi and admire how it crashes through a narrow canyon. Remember the image, as tomorrow you will see what it looks like 200 miles downriver. You can then pass the people bungee jumping into no man’s land and find a troop of baboons standing guard over a walking trail back to Victoria Falls. You will then step into Zambia with your first stop the falls, crossing narrow bridges to cataracts in the river, completing your journey along the length of Victoria Falls. David Livingstone provided the name, and there is a small museum dedicated to his travels, which once followed a route not dissimilar to your own. The town is named in his honor, and it is worth an afternoon away from nature to visit the colorful local markets among the attractions the guides can take you to. Spend the night at a grand lodge close to the Falls, your first night in Zambia perched high above the famous river.

dayInfo.title: Lower Zambezi National Park – Snorkeling Elephants
dayInfo.description: You crossed a bridge to Zambia, but wild animals do not have that luxury and must swim, traversing the river in search of fresher food, continually moving between Mana Pools National Park (Zimbabwe) and Lower Zambezi National Park (Zambia). The former is extremely wild, with little tourist infrastructure. The Zambian side makes the wilderness accessible, while still maintaining its primitive charm. Sometimes all you see of an elephant herd are the trunks, poking out like snorkels above a reef. Buffalo swim slowly, keeping their heads clear of splashing water. Hippos do not actually swim, but rather sink to the riverbed and walk, their immense lungs holding a single breath for more than five minutes. You will see all three of these species from your suite, the daily comings and goings of the Zambezi intimately admired as you sip on cocktails or coffee. Fly east from Livingstone and most of today is relaxed, so much wildlife to see on the panoramas around the luxury camp. A boat safari continues the tranquil theme, as you cruise past the swimmers and uncover different herds along the banks. On a late-afternoon game drive, you can slowly start to notice the contrasts on this side of the river as it is far more than what you had seen before. Especially in the dry season, the permanent availability of water makes this whole area a magnet for game. And even if it is not seen on a drive or walk, there is a good chance that you will see it migrating past the camp.

dayInfo.title: Lower Zambezi National Park – Iconic Wetland Safari
dayInfo.description: Kudu cluster on the banks and you will be close enough to admire their distinctive markings. Nyala hides in the woodland, large antelope that watch you intently before cantering away. A raucous pack of spotted hyena jogs without pause, looking up at where the vultures circle. On a walking safari, you will be close enough to make out the dissimilarities in stripes and see how every zebra has its own markings. On a boat safari, the hippos are just a few meters away, as are any of the big cats that drink from the shallows. During game drives, it can feel as though you are surrounded by elephants, the herd walking on both sides of the vehicle. Much like Hwange and Matusadona, a multi-day safari in this park is a means of getting closer. Different activities are more suited to witnessing different animals, and as a collective, they enable you to build a broader impression of how the giants go about their day. Create a personalized program over these two days, mixing the game drives with thrilling safari walks, along with the serenity of a boat safari along the Zambezi. A fitting and recommended conclusion to the whole safari is a boat trip that will run the length of the park’s riverfront, gazing one way to Zimbabwe and the other to Zambia. It will feel like your own piece of Africa, personal enough for you to give names to the same elephant bull that passes your verandah every evening.

dayInfo.title: Livingstone – Departure
dayInfo.description: From the park’s small airstrip you can fly back to Lusaka or Livingstone, where the international airports offer a selection of outbound flights. The morning is at your leisure, with the option of a final safari activity before your transfer to the airstrip.

tourName: Raw Africa: Safari in Zimbabwe’s Unknown Parks
placesVisited: Victoria Falls, Chizarira National Park, Matusadona National Park, Mana Pools National Park, Nyanga National Park, Malilangwe Wildlife Reserve
generalInfo: Zimbabwe’s national parks redefine adventure as these are Africa’s wild frontiers. You can walk with rhinos and then disappear into rugged mountains, canoe past hippos and then find carnivores on the ancient plains. This two-week safari explores the country’s mostly unknown and unseen parks with eight distinctive destinations that dance with originality and delight in their wildlife charm. Intrepid and evocative, this is a journey into Africa in ways rarely seen.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – Fresh Perspectives on Victoria Falls
dayInfo.description: Victoria Falls rumbles insatiably into a narrow chasm and spray rises, ascending over 300 meters into the air, visible from your lodge on the Zambezi River. Travel to the falls by boat, and the further you go downriver, the louder the roar of the water. Stop at an island on the precipice to be surrounded by the relentless power of Victoria Falls. Then walk alongside the falls, crossing to the opposite side of the chasm for an immersion in the visuals. The spray rains down and sometimes you get soaked before running for the cover of bushes and appreciating the brief moments when the entire falls are visible in a single view. From here you can descend, to a peaceful spot beneath the falls, ideal for recovering your breath and smiling about the spectacle you have just seen. Return to the lodge by road for a relaxed evening at your lodge.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – Wild Dogs Denning in Zambezi National Park
dayInfo.description: After a relaxed morning, you will travel into the heart of Zambezi National Park to follow the trail of migratory elephants. Hundreds of elephants congregate here, leaving pathways of destruction in the woodland. Buffalo and zebra also fill the panoramas but the focus of the day’s drive are the park’s packs of wild dogs. They create their dens in the dry season from May to October, piecing together natural havens in a similar way to many birds. As the grass levels decrease, you spot them beavering away, majestic carnivores that are difficult to see across most of Africa. Along with the wild dogs, the afternoon drive is a good introduction to safari and an opportunity to get accustomed to Zimbabwe’s wilderness.

dayInfo.title: Chizarira National Park – Remote Wilderness Area
dayInfo.description: Vertical mountain slopes provide a staggering backdrop to Chizarira National Park, giving the park its name: a modification on Chijalila, a local Batonka word meaning “great barrier.” Deep jagged incisions flow beneath the mountains with canyons and ravines engulfed by lush vegetation. Naturally isolated, this 2,000 square kilometer park holds claim to being Zimbabwe’s most remote wilderness. It will be a wild bushland, a pristine landscape where leopards thrive, and a handful of animals find tranquility. Although the game densities are low, two days here will bring encounters with a selection of wildlife. However, the real experience comes from exploring such a remote land as the rocky, broken landscape is quick to make you feel humbled by nature. It will come as a real surprise if you encounter another person here. A four-wheel drive vehicle follows remote tracks before you continue the adventure on foot, wandering amongst an otherworldly landscape that could rival any backcountry experience. Stay in mobile camps and appreciate the solitude, a vast outdoor playground so devoid of human life. Occasionally a springbok skips past, an elephant bull wanders lonely, or buffalo are spotted drinking from clear natural springs. You disappear into the rhythm of nature, tuning your senses into the wild African bush. Chizarira is an excellent early stop on a Zimbabwean itinerary as it really relaxes the body and the mind before you launch into the more game-rich wilderness areas.

dayInfo.title: Matusadona National Park – Tracking the Rhinos
dayInfo.description: Cross Chialila, the great barrier, and keep driving east onto the flat plains of Matusadona National Park. Elephants guide the way towards Lake Kariba, the sapphire centerpiece of the park and the water you look over from a luxurious lodge suite. Rhinos do not leave such an obvious trail, and you will spend a thrilling afternoon following their spoor, traveling with local trackers in search of Africa’s endangered icon. Stop on a clearing and wait, rather than inspect the bushes. Slowly the white rhino emerges, followed by a young calf, both strutting proudly. Goosebumps cover your arms as they walk silently past the vehicle. Black rhinos are smaller, and you will find them cantering into the bushes, one of the very timid individuals that make up the less than 1,000 that are left in the wild. Rhinos are a focal point of the safari experience here, and the guides may also allow you to track them on foot, dependent on localized conditions.

dayInfo.title: Matusadona National Park – Zimbabwe’s Densest Population of Lions
dayInfo.description: In Matusadona, you explore from different angles. Boat safaris take you past a handful of rival hippo pods, the odd yawn revealing an insatiable jaw. Short walks follow some of Africa’s biggest animals, and you can often stand across from elephants and buffalos, and sometimes even rhinos. Drives seek out Zimbabwe’s densest population of lions, their abundance vastly reducing the number of other predators. Prides lounge, sleeping with one eye open, imperceptibly noticing your presence. Lionesses prowl, taking elegant steps towards herds of antelope and zebra. Over two days, you can appreciate the marking of territories as revealed through grunted roars that echo for miles and the ravaged scars on young bachelor males. A safari in Matusadona is also very relaxing, with the lakeshore providing quiet hours after activities.

dayInfo.title: Mana Pools National Park – Canoeing Past the Elephants
dayInfo.description: Follow the Zambezi River east as it emerges out of Lake Kariba and meanders through a steep canyon. After an early-morning transfer by road, you enter Mana Pools National Park on a canoe, paddling with the current. This is big game country, and the animals cover the banks, elephants, and hippos clustered where vegetation rises, plus antelope herds gathered on open floodplains. The canoe safari takes you alongside them, just a few meters of water separating you from tusks and horns. Then the guide leads you off the river, into the maze of channels and lagoons that Mana Pools is famous for. Zebra splashes around, wildebeest slurp besides your paddle, and elephants use their trunks as snorkels. Not only is Mana Pools one of the great examples of untouched Africa, the canoe safaris also brings one of Africa’s most unique perspectives. Accommodation for the next two nights is at a luxury camp on the Zambezi.

dayInfo.title: Mana Pools National Park – Walking among the Herds
dayInfo.description: Beneath the mokolwane palms are herds of buffalo while amongst the ebony trees you see clusters of kudu and eland. Hundred-strong herds of duiker scatter on open clearings. Impala and nyala provide contrasting experiences as the walking safari continues, such profusion of life greeting you at almost every corner. Mana Pools is also relatively unique in that you can safely walk amongst a thick density of big game. The herds surround you, half a dozen antelope species plus the stripes of a zebra. You become part of the landscape, walking in the early morning and late afternoon, joining the movement on the plains. Alternatively, switch one of the walks for a game drive that follows the park’s leopards and lions.

dayInfo.title: Nyanga National Park – Hiking and Birding in Resplendent Mountains
dayInfo.description: Fly south today on a small chartered aircraft taking you to the Eastern Highlands, a stunning mountain landscape that includes Zimbabwe’s highest peak. This is a breathtaking landscape of hiking trails, part alpine ruggedness, part desert wilderness. For an escape into nature, there are few places like it in Southern Africa. You will follow a two-day trail through the park beneath strange pinnacles, gazing down on escarpments of color. Birdlife is prolific and the wildlife focus of the walk, over 300 species fluttering around a park of perennial rivers. There is a break from the big game here, although two days usually include encounters with monkeys and small antelope. Instead, this experience takes you back to basics and the humbling experience of unknown Africa.

dayInfo.title: Malilangwe Wildlife Reserve and Gonarezhou National Park – Classic Big Five Safari Without the Crowds
dayInfo.description: Fly south and enter the Great Limpopo Transfrontier Park, a vast unspoiled wilderness that covers three countries and spans an area bigger than many US states. There are no fences here with elephants, rhinos, and buffalos among those that roam widely. To the south is South Africa’s Kruger National Park, one of Africa’s most popular safari destinations. This region blurs seamlessly into Zimbabwe’s Gonarezhou National Park, home to the same assortment and abundance of animals, but with hardly another person in sight. Follow the map a little further north, and you will see Malilangwe, a private wildlife reserve bordering Gonarezhou. Permanent water makes this reserve a crowded meeting point for animals who cluster in the far north of The Great Limpopo Transfrontier Park. Two different safari experiences are available here and they are ideal for the final days of a safari. In Malilangwe, the safari is almost impossibly easy. Giant elephant bulls, secretive nyala and rhinos, herds of zebra and wildebeest, a propensity of predators including leopards and cheetahs all abound as this compact Big Five reserve is quick to showcase the wildest of Africa’s mammals without you having to drive too far. The region is also home to Zimbabwe’s best luxury lodge and is operated by the same people behind many of Africa’s best lodges, Singita. After the intrepid adventure of the last ten days, three nights at this lodge will return you to decadence and extravagance with a swimming pool visited by elephants, fine dining beneath the stars, huge suites with balconies overlooking the park, and the service you would expect from one of Africa’s finest properties. You can walk and game drive in the private reserve, creating a personalized program of activities that makes the best of this game-rich landscape. Activities are usually for two to three hours, leaving lots of time to relax at the lodge. The other option, which is highly recommended for one of your days, is a full-day drive into neighboring Gonarezhou National Park. You will see the same animals, but they are more widely spread with a sense of openness accompanying a drive through the shimmering red valleys. Safari is about surprise, and nowhere is this better illustrated than Gonarezhou, a wilderness that few people know about and even fewer have explored, even if it’s a continuation of the Kruger. Exploring the park means you take a picnic and create your own trails, an inspiring way to finish your journey through unknown Africa.

dayInfo.title: Malilangwe Wildlife Reserve to Johannesburg – Departure
dayInfo.description: From Malilangwe, you take a scheduled flight to Johannesburg in South Africa to meet your international flight that will take you home.

tourName: Signature One-Week Zimbabwe Safari
placesVisited: Victoria Falls, Zambezi River, Hwange National Park, Mana Pools National Park
generalInfo: Zimbabwe will take you closer as photography hides abound for your easy viewing as you walk amongst elephants, take a boat with hippos nearby and antelopes run through your camp. Your weeklong safari will explore the heart of the country’s experience with days packed with unique safari activities, breathtaking encounters, and authentic luxury accommodations. There will be hardly anyone else around on your as you discover the big-game beauty of Victoria Falls, Hwange, and Mana Pools, all destinations as distinctive as the country they define.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – Sunset Dinner Cruise and the Charms of the Zambezi
dayInfo.description: Land in Victoria Falls and you will likely expect the roaring river, the giant waterfall, and perhaps even the baboons. But check into the tented camp, and there’s a herd of elephants welcoming you. Hippos are down in the water below, and a zebra herd is grazing next to your suite. It’s all an indication of how wildlife plays an essential role almost everywhere in Zimbabwe. Your camp is set within its own wildlife reserve, with the prime attraction being the animal that gives the camp its name. Spend the afternoon relaxing at the camp, watching more than just elephants wander past, opening your ears to the strange sounds of the bush. There are only a handful of guests in the entire reserve, helping to ensure tranquility after the flight. As the afternoon ebbs away, you glide along the Zambezi, a dinner cruise opening up the wonders of this famous waterway. Hippos are emerging from the water just as you’re served your starter. Nile crocodiles are sloping into the water as sunset tones ripple across the water. Dessert is accompanied by haunting sounds, the monkeys piping up and the baboons guiding you back towards the camp.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – The Majestic Falls From the Land and the Air
dayInfo.description: Victoria Falls is different from each angle. Take a boat to the precipice where the water roars past and a thunderous growl of falling water fills your ears. Walk along a mystical trail, the falls appearing and then disappearing as you journey through the forest. Then the trees come to an end, and you’re alone with a mile-wide sheet of water. Spray splashes up from the chasm, and you get soaked in seconds, something that’s an essential part of the experience. Next, you see the spectacle from the air, a helicopter soaring above the river, bringing the dreamy visuals of Zimbabwe’s most famous sight. So many colors collide; floodplains and forests, remote islands and roaring water, a narrow crevasse, and the rising clouds of spray. Return to camp and the rest of the day is at your leisure, time to put your feet up and enjoy the wildlife of the reserve.

dayInfo.title: Hwange National Park – Brilliance of the Big Game Safari Experience
dayInfo.description: Reach Hwange by light aircraft, and new animals keep you company around the camp. There are paw prints in the surrounding sand, indications of just how close you are to the predators, notably resident cheetahs and hyenas. Of course, there are still plenty of elephants, Hwange being famous for the trunk-swinging giants. Giraffes are equally prevalent in your first impressions with their vibrant orange markings that contrast the lush green of the grassland. The hide is nestled between Hwange’s two main habitats, hidden in the acacia woodland, and gazing over the open plains. There is no better location for experiencing Hwange’s wildlife. And what wildlife! Serval and caracal leave their prints around the camp, kudu and bushbuck roam through the camp, and you soon learn the difference between duiker and impala. Your stylish suite is beneath a cooling patch of forest, featuring a private veranda that’s perched above a waterhole. Over these three days, you’ll intimately understand the habits of those that drink there: elephants, giraffes, zebra, kudu, and buffalo. Interiors are full of rustic luxury, helping maintain a connection with the wild. Each day you will build your own program of safari activities, choosing up to four a day. Combine walks, drives during the day and night, and experience the unique vantage point of photography hides. The idea is to provide an encompassing experience, helping you connect with the raw essence of Hwange.

dayInfo.title: Hwange National Park – Personalizing Your Dream Safari Program in Hwange
dayInfo.description: A game drive at sunrise is an ideal time to find black-maned lions on the move. Suspense floats on the breeze as you see a pride loping toward a herd of blue wildebeest. The ungulates are quick, but the lionesses are many, and the scene captivates you for over an hour. Spend the middle part of the morning in one of the sunken hides, concealed from those who visit the waterhole. An elephant herd arrives, and you stare straight down at their trunks. Admire the tusks on the old bulls, then laugh at the antics of babies who chase warthogs and duiker away from the water. Of course, this is just an example of how the day could look, as the actual program will depend on your mood. It’s more specific than just activities. If there are particular animals you’re interested in, they can become the focus of any activity. After lunch, you take a walk and learn how to track steenbok and gemsbok, imposing antelopes that leave obvious clues. Footsteps crunch onto the dirt and you pass the giants, including buffalo and giraffe that give you a funny look. Within 20 minutes you’re amongst the herds, exploring the facial emotion, and understanding the peculiar behavior, and means of communication. The walk continues, and you may encounter any of the Hwange residents, other than the big predators. Relax at the camp, then complete the day with a nighttime drive, a journey that seeks out leopards on the move. A spotlight stops and the spotted hunter looks your way, lucid blue-green eyes revealing a calm menace. The leopard’s hunt continues, and your eyes must adjust to the moonlight and sounds, something that doesn’t produce great photos but creates a thrilling appreciation of the savannah at night.

dayInfo.title: Hwange National Park – More Than Just Lions and Elephants
dayInfo.description: Visit Africa and certain animals are always high on the list. Elephants are unmissable in Zimbabwe; you’ll find them wherever you go. Lions are just as present in Hwange and Mana Pools. Leopards are an elusive sight but one that’s captured on a five-day safari. You’ll also experience rhinos, the endangered giant that is far more graceful than you might expect. On a morning game drive, the guide stops, seemingly in the middle of nowhere. Look around, and you see nothing. But slowly, meticulously, a white rhino and its calf amble out of the bushes. Refusing to change course, they walk straight past the vehicle. It’s a heart-racing moment, and your finger quivers on the camera shutter as you caption the image of this imposing creature; so proud and undaunted. Keep exploring, because Hwange is home to over 100 mammal species. Some are found in the woodland, others on the open savannah, and still more on vast Kalahari grasslands that can be visited on longer game drives. You will track packs of wild dogs and you will discover that there is something mystical about their effortless nomadic journeys. Seek out the rare civet and aardwolf, in the early morning or after dark. Discover one of Africa’s largest cheetah populations. Walk across the plains to truly admire the horns of roan and sable antelope, arguably Africa’s most impressive antelope species. On a single game drive, you’re likely to see two-dozen species. While on a two-hour bushwalk, you might meet 12 – 15 ungulate species, including those that are rarely seen outside Zimbabwe. Immersive and intriguing, Hwange takes you beyond traditional notions of safari. It is a park bigger than some US states, and it feels like you have it all to yourself.

dayInfo.title: Mana Pools National Park – World Heritage Wetlands
dayInfo.description: In Hwange, you see the dust spiral, and the nomads go on an endless search for water. In Mana Pools there’s water everywhere, bringing lush exotic colors and a sense of excess. Animals migrate here during the dry season, knowing there is permanent goodness in the rivers and lakes. To see them all, you are best starting off in a boat, cruising along the banks, as hundreds of mammals come to drink. A motorboat is followed by a canoe, a narrow vessel that travels into a complex web of canals. Now you are even closer, barely steps away from hippos yawning and buffalo drinking. Occasionally there are eyes hidden in the grass, like those of a lioness laying an ambush, waiting for an impala herd to drop their guard. Fly to Mana Pools and check into your next camp, a remote outpost that’s ideally situated for canoe and walking safaris. This modern camp is arguably the park’s first genuine ultra-luxe lodge, with glass-walled tents offering uninterrupted river views. Elephants are just the start of the visitors here, with nyala and spotted hyenas also regularly heard and seen around the camp. Both side-striped and black-backed jackals operate on the camp’s outskirts, stealthy figures you may spot when opening the curtains. Wetlands mean food. There’s grass to graze, fruit to find, and easy pickings for the park’s predators. You’ll find that the liquid bounty creates drama. Not just with the lions and leopards, but with breathtaking hunting displays by wild dogs, and scrappy battles amongst the smaller predators.

dayInfo.title: Mana Pools National Park – Exploring All the Perspectives
dayInfo.description: Step, step, step, you walk tentatively onto the floodplain at sunrise. Nyala jump past, twisted horns making them almost the same height as you are. Impalas are scattered everywhere, and it’s as if they are dancing the ballet, dainty skips sending them clear off the grass. A herd of buffalo stares at you, chewing without pause. Following subtle tracks, you go in search of zebra, finding them grazing on the plains. Take a step closer and wait. The zebras appear uninterested. So you get closer, watching for any change in behavior. Zebra eyes meet yours, and you admire how every set of black and white stripes is different, their version of our fingerprints. Then an elephant starts rumbling across the pan, and the guide gets you back to a safe distance. Over both days here in Mana Pools, you build your own safari program, mixing water and land-based activities as you please. Walking is one perspective. Drives provide another, further opportunities to trace the predators. But the great highlight here is a kayak safari into the channels. It’s quiet, hardly a sound made by the guide’s paddle. Every sound is appreciated; the rustling of grazers, the grunt of hippos and buffalo, an elephant bull digging beneath the riverbed. And it feels like every corner you turn brings another intimate sight. From the water, you get astonishingly close to Africa’s biggest mammals.

dayInfo.title: Mana Pools to Harare – Final Safari Memories and Departure
dayInfo.description: Complete your safari experience with a final morning activity, before returning to the camp for brunch, and a leisurely few hours watching the wildlife at the river. You then fly back to Harare by light aircraft and transfer to your international flight.

tourName: Zimbabwe Dry Season Safari: June to September
placesVisited: Victoria Falls, Zambezi River, Zambezi National Park, Hwange National Park, Mana Pools National Park, Matusadona National Park, Lake Kariba
generalInfo: Wild dogs denning, rhinos roaming, lions and leopards hunting and elephants congregating around parched waterholes abound as you visit Zimbabwe in the dry season. You can explore some of Africa’s greatest safari scenes at the ultimate time of the year as the months between June to September are prime for exceptional wildlife sightings. However, unlike many other African destinations, Zimbabwe’s dry season is not crowded with tourists, so the region will be like your own wilderness playground.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – Sunset Cruise on the Iconic Zambezi River
dayInfo.description: There is something spectacular about a Zambezi River cruise at sunset as the golden colors bounce off of the water as your sunset cruise offers an idyllic atmosphere. Landscapes of blue and green stretch out with nothing artificial breaking nature’s spell. At the same time, there are moments of drama with hippos barreling out of the water and Nile crocodiles menacingly sulking into the river. Nothing feels real as the combination of fine dining and cocktails meets four-legged giants and unbroken wilderness. This experience on the Zambezi River is just an introduction, as you can expect a similar atmosphere in all the destinations on this safari with a rich mix of contemporary luxury and the authenticity of wild Africa.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – Zambezi National Park for Wild Dog Denning Season
dayInfo.description: Spend the morning relaxing at the lodge, watching the baboons jump past and admiring the odd hippo returning to the riverfront. In the afternoon, you can drive to nearby Zambezi National Park, a small and understated park that offers a perfect introduction to safari. You will see an elephant for the first time, along with a handful of other African favorites: zebra, wildebeest, buffalo. But the main reason you are here is to find wild dogs, who make their dens during these dry season months. They scamper and scurry, moving nimbly as they construct homes that will survive the rains. Seeing them so active is a highlight of any African safari and the premier reason to make this relaxed stop at Zambezi National Park. Returning to the lodge, you will dine beneath ebony trees on the edge of the water.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – The Perfect Time of Year to View Victoria Falls
dayInfo.description: Victoria Falls changes with the seasons, and at the end of the green season, around March, the waterfall is in peak flow and completely consumed by the spray that rises back out of the chasm. Visit in October and November, and the river is low, Victoria Falls beautiful but lacking power. June and July are a perfect time, the thundering water roaring past with relentless speed, the spray rising but not interrupting the photography. Take a boat to the edge of the falls and hear the thundering of the world’s most powerful waterfall, and then explore walking trails that run parallel to the falls, a series of viewpoints revealing rainbows illuminated in the spray. Occasionally, you might be consumed by spray, yet most of the trail offers an uninterrupted view onto the spectacle. There is also an option to helicopter over the falls should you wish while later in the afternoon, you can cruise the Zambezi for a second time, dining at sunset.

dayInfo.title: Hwange National Park – Elephants Crowding Around the Watering Hole
dayInfo.description: This morning you fly south, touching down on dusty plains parched of water. This southern section of Hwange is expressive and open, the Kalahari extending in all directions, the nomads emerging from the hazy heat that hangs on the horizon. Water is scarce during the dry season, so animals start to huddle around the surviving waterholes, or they make long dangerous journeys in search of something better. Spurts of dust follow elephant and giraffe while zebra marches in their hundreds. Kudu and springbok cluster together, black-maned lions prowl with their coats blending into the golden colors of the plains. Safari is both charming and dramatic at this time of year, Zimbabwe’s flagship park coming into peak game-viewing season. After the flight, you can spend the day on game drives, exploring the diversity of life. Back at the lodge, you gaze across at elephants crowding around a floodlit waterhole.

dayInfo.title: Hwange National Park – Classic Big Game Safari
dayInfo.description: Follow the lions in the light of dawn, hungry lionesses continuing their nighttime hunt. They are getting desperate, the short grass making it hard to hide and difficult to get close. Wildebeest see them coming, and they gallop into the distance, the rumble of hooves heard as well as seen. As the safari continues, you may lose track of the elephants, so many of them converging with enthusiastic calves, boisterous infants, melancholy matriarchs, large herds, and lone bulls with astonishing tusks. Slowly, you will come to recognize the antelopes and able to distinguish the hartebeest from the eland, the impala from the roan antelope. Rhinos also occupy this park, and these months are the best time to find them with the diminishing bushes making it harder for a shy creature and harder to find quiet tranquility. And spending three days, you will have a great chance to see leopards, the stealthiest of the predators using the most surreptitious of methods to place an ambush at the waterholes. During these two days, you will mostly explore on game drives, which take you on a tour of the permanent waterholes, discovering the densest concentrations of wildlife. Walks are also a possibility, the dry plains opening up the greater possibility to walk safely through the big game of Africa. Like everywhere on this safari, the activities are completely private, and you have room to customize your own program. There are over 100 mammal species here, and in the dry season, you could expect to see over 50. Downtime at the lodge is when you admire the elephants, the herds, and the nomads that come to drink from the waterholes beneath your tented suite. At this time in the year, the safari never ends, and you will drift to sleep as elephants are hooting nearby.

dayInfo.title: Mana Pools National Park – Walking and Canoeing in a Big-Game Landscape
dayInfo.description: An elephant returns your gaze, trunk swinging above your head as buffalos stare at your canoe, their bulk and power best appreciated from your unique vantage point as zebra and wildebeest splash in the shallows, barely five meters away. Mana Pools has a similar assortment of animals to Hwange, particularly the most iconic species, so its allure comes from the diversity of activities with canoe and walking safaris giving you an entirely different perspective. This park is never busy, and even in the prime dry season, it is unlikely that you will see more than a handful of other visitors over two days. Silent and surreal, the activities enable you to get much closer to the animals as you paddle down natural canals with elephants drinking from banks just a few meters away. You walk across plains, joining the herds that wander and canter and when the activities are over, you relax at the camp, overlooking the Zambezi River to watch hippos and buffalos swimming past.

dayInfo.title: Mana Pools National Park – Fabulous Game Viewing in a Park That’s Never Crowded
dayInfo.description: Two more perspectives are presented this morning as you game drive at dawn, the best time to find the park’s predators and notably a population of leopards that hide in palms and fig trees. Then, continue by motorboat, a noisier and faster means of travel, and one that enables you to traverse the length of the park in search of the best game densities. Although you cannot get as close, the motorboat helps you to uncover the parties of animals on the Zambezi’s banks in areas closed to vehicle access. The afternoon is free, and you can choose from any of the activities with your private safari continuing in one of Africa’s great wetland parks.

dayInfo.title: Matusadona National Park (Lake Kariba) – In Search of Zimbabwe’s Black and White Rhinos
dayInfo.description: A short charter flight follows the Zambezi back upriver, just four seats in a small plane that offers a window onto Zimbabwe’s wild scale. Matusadona is compact yet remote, a national park defined by the soothing waters of Lake Kariba. Check into your lodge, and it initially feels like this is the waterside escape that comes at the end of the safari. But things are not as it seems, as soon, out of the trees comes an elephant, a big bull marching through. In the distance, you see springbok and zebra clustered on open plains, and when you explore the area around the lodge, you will find black and white rhinos, both subspecies of Africa’s endangered icon. Matusadona is two destinations in one as the lake provides gentle views and an atmosphere of tranquility and the surroundings offer Zimbabwe’s great concentrations of wildlife with the rare chance to spot both species of rhino on a single drive.

dayInfo.title: Matusadona National Park – Lakeside Escapism
dayInfo.description: White rhinos barge across the land, horns pointing proudly, eyes staring intently. They don’t rush, as they are comfortable with their size and confident that nothing will interrupt their equanimity. Black rhinos are smaller and much timider, generally preferring to hide out in thick bushes. It is unlikely that you will see them after 10 am, as they usually return to the dense vegetation. Game drives in Matusadona are the best way to see these rhinos, but there is also an exclusive possibility to track them on foot, particularly the white rhinos when they rest in the midday sun. As with each day, your program is private and flexible, game drives and walking safari complemented by short trips on the lake, where wonderful crowds of birds keep bringing new impressions to the safari. Spend the mornings exploring, or spend them lounging by the lake. Take footsteps through the forest to follow the elephants, or create footprints in the sand with an afternoon on the beach a rejuvenating way to complete a day of safari. Drive into the park’s remote corners with a bottle of champagne and a picnic lunch, or keep the activities to less than two hours, giving you more time to savor the view from your suite verandah. You can opt to spend more time along the lakeshore where there is more wildlife, or you can move into the woodland, where it is easier to get closer, particularly to Zimbabwe’s highest density of lions. In some parks, it can feel like you are missing out if you are not exploring at every minute of the day. In Matusadona, you are always comfortable with the blend of atmospheres making for the classic end to a Zimbabwe safari.

dayInfo.title: Matusadona National Park to Victoria Falls – Departure
dayInfo.description: It is a short flight along the Zambezi back to Victoria Falls, completing your loop around Zimbabwe. Upon landing, a representative will assist you in transferring to your onward departure with so many memories of big game Africa fresh in the memory.

tourName: Zimbabwe Green Season Safari: December to March
placesVisited: Victoria Falls, Zambezi River, Hwange National Park, Ngamo Plains, Matobo Hills National Park, Bulawayo
generalInfo: Embrace the feeling of having wild Africa as your private safari playground by exploring Zimbabwe during the green season. Calves are nurtured on the plains as predators are lurking with big game concentrates in astonishing numbers before each sets off on separate migrations. Victoria Falls gushes with remarkable intensity and from December to March, there is hardly another person in sight as it is just you and some of the very best of an African safari. This 10-day safari will celebrate the best of it all.

dayInfo.title: Victoria Falls – The Rising Waters of the Zambezi
dayInfo.description: Sporadic bursts of thunder swell the Zambezi and its tributaries as the water levels rise and the river picks up speed to surge past your lodge on the banks. Hippos must move and relocate to pools protected by giant boulders.
